comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jorgedragon] Thank you! It's great to get that kind of information. Since the photo is taken from the Generalife - should it then be the Nasrid Palaces that shows on the picture? And the Albaicín area to the right ?
/Anna B.

comment.author: 31990443@N04
comment._content:
i thought it was clear (the nasrid palaces and the unfinished Charles V Palace -the big square building with round yard, its upper gallery with no roof-, at left), and in some way, I was talking to myself   :-)  , because i was a week before near there (in Silla del Moro tower), and shot this linked photo, remembering Curman image... 

but no, Curman didn't climbed to Silla del Moro, his photo is from Generalife, possibly the upper open galleries in this summer pavillion we see down at right in this image.   

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jorgedragon/6517876547/in/set-72157611183098937/]

Unfortunately, in a quick search in flickr, i have not found any image from the exact place, possibly because now is not allowed the public access to the upper galleries.

Bernd H. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/berndh/] made this photo in Generalife near the Curman one, but from the walled galleries :[http://www.flickr.com/photos/berndh/5418266066/sizes/o/in/photostream/]

the urban area in Curman photo seems is mostly the proper city and the western part of albaicín , maybe you can send me by email a bigger detail of urban area portion and it could be possible to localize the church we see at right,.

comment.author: 31990443@N04
comment._content: Inverse view from the Alhambra palaces: the Silla del Moro tower (up) and the Generalife palace, down, in a photo of M. Cascales, taken in the 90's. At left, with white wall, the open galleries, the place where possibly Curman shot this photo. [lacomunidad.elpais.com/blogfiles/manolo-1925/GENERALIFEYS...]

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
jorge dragón [testing flickr]: You have been to a great help to improve our information on this photo (and others) and I have learned a lot about The Alhambra thanks to you! :) 
Your own photo as well as the photo by Bernd H are really beautiful - thanks for posting!
/Anna B.
